reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “multiplicative fragility” move (Section 2.4), which is an important engine for the intuitive claim that mostly-great futures are rare even conditional on broadly good outcomes; however, it is not the only major support for “no easy eutopia” (the later ‘fussy views’ analysis in Section 3 is independent), so centrality is moderate rather than maximal. The objection has real bite: a product-of-dimensions toy model does rely on (approximate) independence/low correlation to generate the extreme right-skew and ‘one miss ruins most value’ typicality; with strong positive correlation (or shared causal drivers), the distribution can be much less skewed and mostly-high outcomes become more common. Still, it does not fully refute the targeted claim: (i) the paper already gestures at “relatively independent factors” and uses the product model as a toy/illustration, so the critique partly attacks a simplified model rather than the whole argument; (ii) even with correlation, multiplicative sensitivity can remain, and ‘single-flaw’ failure modes can persist if some factors have heavy left tails or are governed by different mechanisms; (iii) the broader thesis can survive via the Section 3 argument that many plausible moral views are fussy for structural reasons unrelated to independence. The critique is largely correct about the mathematical/structural role of independence and about the directional effect of positive correlation on the toy model’s skew, though it somewhat overstates how much the skew necessarily “collapses” and how essential strict independence is to any fragility claim. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: Correlated dimensions undermine fragility model's skewed outcomes
